drugDrugCheck.shortText: AMIODARONE HCL (PACERONE) 200MG TAB and AMANTADINE HCL 100MG CAP may interact based on the potential interaction between AMIODARONE and POSSIBLE QT PROLONGING AGENTS.

professionalMonograph.disclaimer: This information is generalized and not intended as specific medical advice. Consult your healthcare professional before taking or discontinuing any drug or commencing any course of treatment.
professionalMonograph.monographTitle: MONOGRAPH TITLE: Amiodarone/Possible QT Prolonging Agents
professionalMonograph.severityLevel: SEVERITY LEVEL: 2-Severe Interaction: Action is required to reduce the risk of severe adverse interaction.
professionalMonograph.mechanismOfAction: MECHANISM OF ACTION: Amiodarone has been shown to prolong the QTc interval. Concurrent use with other agents that prolong the QTc interval may result in additive effects on the QTc interval.(1,2)
professionalMonograph.clinicalEffects: CLINICAL EFFECTS: The concurrent use of amiodarone with other agents that prolong the QTc interval may result in potentially life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias, including torsades de pointes.(1,2)
professionalMonograph.predisposingFactors: PREDISPOSING FACTORS: The risk of QT prolongation may be increased by cardiovascular disease, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, bradycardia, and the concurrent use of agents that inhibit amiodarone metabolism.
professionalMonograph.patientManagement: PATIENT MANAGEMENT: The Australian manufacturer of amiodarone states that concurrent use of agents known to cause torsades de pointes is contraindicated.(1)The US manufacturer of amiodarone states that the need to co-administer amiodarone with any other drug known to prolong the QTc interval must be based on a careful assessment of the potential risks and benefits of doing so for each patient.(2)
professionalMonograph.discussion: DISCUSSION: QTc prolongation has been reported during concurrent amiodarone and fluoroquinolones and macrolide antibiotics.Agents that are linked to this monograph may have been associated with Torsades de Pointes and/or QT prolongation but at this time lack substantial evidence for causing Torsades de Pointes.(3)

references.reference: 1.Cordarone X (amiodarone hydrochloride) Australian prescribing information. Sanofi-Synthelabo Australia Pty Limited Augsut 15, 2007.
2.Cordarone (amiodarone hydrochloride) US prescribing information. Wyeth Pharmaceuticals April, 2009.

3.The University of Arizona Center for Education and Research of Therapeutics. Drugs with Risk of Torsades de Pointes and Drugs with Possible Risk of Torsades de Pointes. Available at: http://www.torsades.org. Updated Dec 17, 2002.
